@HorrorYearbook thank you, spooky butthole, I will now shut up.
@dloehr I love this. As a father myself, I blame the toxic "What's your favorite color" discourse for planting the seeds early.

Hi, I'm Dan Kwan, one of the directors of EEAAO. I appreciate your love of the film, but maybe next time you can try to cool it on the aggression. This place is filled w/ shitty discourse, don't add to it (what would Waymond do?). Don't feel bad, its tough to keep ur cool here. https://t.co/4YVXI8B4UF
Anyways, if anyone spots a fan who gets too excited and crosses a line, please feel free to send them this tweet below:

(all of the above applies to the rest of the Oscar season, especially after the nominations/winners are announced. seriously fam,  I want to see absolutely no bullies, no meanies, no buttheads acting out on behalf of our film post-Oscar announcements.)

Our work has always been polarizing (see: Swiss Army Man discourse), and that is wonderful. To even be a part of the conversation is an honor. To have created something that has connected with so many passionate people is enough (seriously please no more validation, I'm drowning)

Next time you see something about our film that makes you angry, take a step back, remind yourself why you fell in love with our movie. Those feelings are infinitely more important to you than any list from some critic who has a completely different lived experience from you.

I am so grateful to the fans who love this film and have made it their own. I know for many, this story and characters mean a lot so any slight towards the film feels like a personal attack, but lashing out does everyone a disservice (and is counteractive to the film's message).
A healthy industry requires a diverse range of films finding their own versions of success. Every list that deviates from the norm should be celebrated (unless they're shilling problematic shit hah)

These end of year lists are a great opportunity for people to discover films they haven't heard of (our film doesn't need that), to help smaller films make money (don't need that), and to celebrate the hard work of filmmakers we admire (don't need anymore celebrating).

This was an incredible year for movies and there is so much to celebrate, why waste your time on anger? (its a rhetorical question, I know the algorithms have been training us to chase these emotions, capitalism has taught us to see everything as a zero sum game blah blah blah)

I know the end of year discourse on film twitter can be toxic af with all of the "Best of" lists that come out, but this really needs to stop. The act of ranking any piece of art is so absurd and should only be seen as an incredibly personal and subjective endeavor.
The algorithm pushed this onto my timeline, and as one of the people who made the film, this aggression will not stand, man. 🧵🧵🧵 https://t.co/VQBsZG2Kjr
RT @HrishiHirway: Like every reasonable person, I adored "Everything Everywhere All at Once," and I'm so thrilled we got to make this episo…

@tvaziri Have you had a chance to see it? How does it feel? (Pardon my ignorance if you worked on it Todd hahah)

@ebenbolter Thanks, that makes sense, I’m just having a hard time imagining the intended effect of having FG and BG at different frame rates, for something that is meant to feel photorealistic (could totally see something stylized like Spiderverse using this technique tho)

I've been trying to examine our devotion to the ideal of free speech now that certain groups are exploiting the corpse of "free speech" as a shield to protect their right to spread the most inhumane and cruel ideas. This was one of the most clear-eyed responses I've heard so far.

urls.title: Elon, Twitter and the Gladiator Arena
urls.description: Since it’s looking more and more like Elon Musk, CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, will probably soon have ownership of Twitter, we wanted to do a special episode about what this could mean for Twitter users and our global digital democracy as a whole. This is the second part in a two-part conversation about Twitter that we’ve had on Your Undivided Attention about Elon Musk’s bid for Twitter and what it could mean in the context of the need to go in a more humane direction.

data.text:
"When John Stuart Mill wrote the book On Liberty about the need to respect our individual liberties and not to interfere with other people's choices, he didn't write that in the age of synthetic media where we could flood the internet with fake speech..."

https://t.co/TqQ7ugB4yZ

As Elon continues to piss all over the Fourth Estate without any regard to how important it is to a functioning democracy, I'll point you to an interesting episode of Your Undivided Attention that pokes at the heart of why the Free Speech vs Censorship debate has been so slippery https://t.co/dTd3lXPSlp
Kudos to all of us on here still diligently tweeting as if the ship is not going down. It has been a privilege and an honor 🫡 https://t.co/Oljt0sSwu8
@DFLEISCHERCAMP heck yeahhhhhh

*a more reasonable and less optimized-for-the-algorithm response: he may think this is a necessary business decision during an economic downturn after a massive boom in “content” creation incentivized by streaming wars, but it’s still a shitty way to talk about people’s work.

When the very institutions that produce our stories can’t see the worth of stories beyond their economic value, so much is lost. 

I know that many of the shows that got cut helped so many people in ways that will never show up on a spreadsheet. https://t.co/hzT1khYC6s

Aftersun floored me. Rewards you for leaning in, but in the end knocks you back for getting too close. Raw slice-of-life handheld gives way to ingenious and poetic shot design. I am going to be thinking about those few final moments for a long time. Bravo. https://t.co/Z1KuGJ1XoP

RT @curious_founder: Recently I learned about a man who has trained 1,000+ people to block wind and solar projects. 

I read through all hi…
@richbrian 👑👑👑
@therebeccasun @lsirikul @allatoncemovie @A24 Spot on! I know how much work goes into these looks!

@byMatthewBest @kurtjenkins And when so many studies have already shown that the way the current system decides what content is amplified and what content is buried can lead to a rise in teen depression, polarization, misinformation this is less a convo about censorship and more one about public health.
@byMatthewBest @kurtjenkins I’m sorry I haven’t been super clear. I’m not advocating for regulating/censoring content. I’m advocating for the regulation of the algorithms that deliver the content.
@JohnFactorial Good luck!

@JohnFactorial I think reminding people of the magic of local community is one of the most important battles. But I also know that its an uphill battle, you are literally fighting algos designed by trillion $ corps. I hope I didn’t come off as dismissive, love that you’re doing the good work.
@kurtjenkins *pardon the typos and bad grammar, 🤓

@kurtjenkins What I’m saying is, whenever people talk about regulations, they jump to worst case scenarios (which are important to be aware of) but we need to leave room for all the messe and  nuancethat comes with democracy.

@kurtjenkins But that doesn’t mean there isn’t nuance for everything else on the spectrum (eg. nudity is not allowed unless on paid cable, etc) where things that you’ve mentioned like personal choice come into play.

@kurtjenkins But if you use the FCC as a better analog to this convo surrounding social media, there are hard fast rules that we all agree shouldn’t exist on TV (child porn, tobacco ads) that has been banned because we understand the objective social harm they do.

@kurtjenkins Yes, the EPA has to make objective decisions to protect us, but it also has to make a ton of subjective decisions on a spectrum of degrees of regulations (and might I add, often doing not a great job at that, like I said messy).
@kurtjenkins Haha thanks for the thoughtful discourse. Really appreciate any chance to have civilized conversation on this site.

@dunkwun @HorrorYearbook Please don't. Also I enjoyed your movie and several others this year. It is hard to overlap laugh crying with actual crying as much as y'all did with your movie. Thank you for the catharsis.

-Pooptoad
@dunkwun Shut up and let the adults talk

@dunkwun Well said. My younger son started asking "what's your favorite _____? what's #1?" when he was little, and we've raised him not to worry about ranking. So many books and movies, so many moods from day to day, I'm happy to have things I love for any mood, any time.
Anyways, if anyone spots a fan who gets too excited and crosses a line, please feel free to send them this tweet below:

(all of the above applies to the rest of the Oscar season, especially after the nominations/winners are announced. seriously fam,  I want to see absolutely no bullies, no meanies, no buttheads acting out on behalf of our film post-Oscar announcements.)

Our work has always been polarizing (see: Swiss Army Man discourse), and that is wonderful. To even be a part of the conversation is an honor. To have created something that has connected with so many passionate people is enough (seriously please no more validation, I'm drowning)

Next time you see something about our film that makes you angry, take a step back, remind yourself why you fell in love with our movie. Those feelings are infinitely more important to you than any list from some critic who has a completely different lived experience from you.

I am so grateful to the fans who love this film and have made it their own. I know for many, this story and characters mean a lot so any slight towards the film feels like a personal attack, but lashing out does everyone a disservice (and is counteractive to the film's message).
A healthy industry requires a diverse range of films finding their own versions of success. Every list that deviates from the norm should be celebrated (unless they're shilling problematic shit hah)

These end of year lists are a great opportunity for people to discover films they haven't heard of (our film doesn't need that), to help smaller films make money (don't need that), and to celebrate the hard work of filmmakers we admire (don't need anymore celebrating).

This was an incredible year for movies and there is so much to celebrate, why waste your time on anger? (its a rhetorical question, I know the algorithms have been training us to chase these emotions, capitalism has taught us to see everything as a zero sum game blah blah blah)

I know the end of year discourse on film twitter can be toxic af with all of the "Best of" lists that come out, but this really needs to stop. The act of ranking any piece of art is so absurd and should only be seen as an incredibly personal and subjective endeavor.
The algorithm pushed this onto my timeline, and as one of the people who made the film, this aggression will not stand, man. 🧵🧵🧵 https://t.co/VQBsZG2Kjr
Like every reasonable person, I adored "Everything Everywhere All at Once," and I'm so thrilled we got to make this episode of Song Exploder. https://t.co/qbKua2Ybh2

@dunkwun To my eye he was dropping down the frame rates on the more human elements, then ramping up for the larger scale action and underwater work. Certain scenes though it’s really jumping up and down cut by cut. I think I even spotted an 80s style 12fps slow-mo double print shot.
@dunkwun wild, eh?

@dunkwun I believe what he was doing was projecting the whole thing at 60fps, then essentially apply a frame doubling effect to certain elements, so printing a foreground character for 2 frames or every other frame, whilst background updates every single frame.

Yo, wtf?

VFR IN THE SAME SHOT https://t.co/6hkinvpiuN

Just saw #AvatarTheWayOfWater in 3D VFR (variable frame rate). Projected at 60fps, Cameron is actually moving between 60,48,30 and 24fps shot by shot, sometimes even during the same shot with foreground elements in different fps to background. Underwater work particularly superb. https://t.co/xxRprwfXuB
@dunkwun Wow me and @dunkwun had the same joke

@dunkwun Second act twist: GDT doesn't want to switch back after a day. He Being John Malkovich's Tay Sway's career into goth-horror operas. There is a six-year time skip before the start of the third act.

urls.title: Ke Huy Quan’s True Hollywood Comeback
urls.description: ‘Indiana Jones’ and ‘The Goonies’ made him a child star in the ’80s. Then Hollywood forgot about him. Nearly 40 years later, Quan opens up about ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ and the part that took a lifetime to find.

urls.title: Elon, Twitter and the Gladiator Arena
urls.description: Since it’s looking more and more like Elon Musk, CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, will probably soon have ownership of Twitter, we wanted to do a special episode about what this could mean for Twitter users and our global digital democracy as a whole. This is the second part in a two-part conversation about Twitter that we’ve had on Your Undivided Attention about Elon Musk’s bid for Twitter and what it could mean in the context of the need to go in a more humane direction.

tweets.text:
"When John Stuart Mill wrote the book On Liberty about the need to respect our individual liberties and not to interfere with other people's choices, he didn't write that in the age of synthetic media where we could flood the internet with fake speech..."

https://t.co/TqQ7ugB4yZ

As Elon continues to piss all over the Fourth Estate without any regard to how important it is to a functioning democracy, I'll point you to an interesting episode of Your Undivided Attention that pokes at the heart of why the Free Speech vs Censorship debate has been so slippery https://t.co/dTd3lXPSlp
As Twitter pursues the goal of elevating citizen journalism, media elite will try everything to stop that from happening
🤪🤪🤪 https://t.co/OWYt4IvPnU

urls.title: David Zaslav defends Warner Bros. Discovery cuts: 'We did not get rid of any show that was helping us'

@lsirikul @allatoncemovie @A24 This is SO GOOD, attn @dunkwun!
@byMatthewBest @kurtjenkins I’m sorry I haven’t been super clear. I’m not advocating for regulating/censoring content. I’m advocating for the regulation of the algorithms that deliver the content.

@dunkwun @kurtjenkins Daniel, first, love Swiss Army Man. But regulation is not the norm. Let's take a movie about a magic farting corpse. Under the self-imposed Hays Code, that movie never would have seen the light of day. When jurisdictions tried to enforce the Hays Code by basing laws on it ...

@JohnFactorial I think reminding people of the magic of local community is one of the most important battles. But I also know that its an uphill battle, you are literally fighting algos designed by trillion $ corps. I hope I didn’t come off as dismissive, love that you’re doing the good work.
@dunkwun You’re absolutely right, a networking concept but not a media one, and its got the classic “not so useful til more users” problem but we are working on it. thanks for the interest!

@kurtjenkins But that doesn’t mean there isn’t nuance for everything else on the spectrum (eg. nudity is not allowed unless on paid cable, etc) where things that you’ve mentioned like personal choice come into play.

@kurtjenkins But if you use the FCC as a better analog to this convo surrounding social media, there are hard fast rules that we all agree shouldn’t exist on TV (child porn, tobacco ads) that has been banned because we understand the objective social harm they do.

@kurtjenkins Yes, the EPA has to make objective decisions to protect us, but it also has to make a ton of subjective decisions on a spectrum of degrees of regulations (and might I add, often doing not a great job at that, like I said messy).

@dunkwun The EPA, for example. It's objective fact that toxic waste in the water supply is a no-no. "Easy."

But regulating social is tricky because you're dealing with subjective expression. 1st amendment stuff that I personally don't trust the gov to tackle.
@dunkwun Big fan, BTW. 👍
